#Text=Bevil Granville
#Text=Arms of Granville : Gules , three clarions or
#Text=Sir Bevil Granville ( died 1706 ) was an English soldier who served as Governor of Pendennis Castle in Cornwall and as Governor of Barbados .
#Text=Origins

#Text=Granville was the eldest son of Bernard Granville ( 1631 – 1701 ) ( 4th son of Sir Bevil Grenville ( 1596 – 1643 ) who died in heroic circumstances at the Battle of Lansdowne ) , Master of the Horse and a Gentleman of the Bedchamber to King Charles II ( 1660 – 1685 ) and MP for Launceston , Saltash , Lostwithiel and Plymouth , [ 1 ] by his wife Anne Morley , daughter and sole heiress of Cuthbert Morley of Hornby , Yorkshire . [ 2 ]
#Text=His uncle was John Granville , 1st Earl of Bath ( 1628 – 1701 ) , of Stowe , Kilkhampton in Cornwall , who played a prominent role in the Restoration of the Monarchy of 1660 .

#Text=His family was descended from Sir Richard I de Grenville ( d. post 1142 ) ( alias de Grainvilla , de Greinvill , etc. ) , one of the Twelve Knights of Glamorgan , of Neath Castle , Glamorgan and of Bideford , Devon and Stowe , Kilkhampton in Cornwall .
#Text=In 1661 [ 3 ] the family changed the spelling of its surname from Grenville to Granville , to emphasise its supposed origins at Granville , Normandy .
#Text=Career
#Text=After keeping his terms at Trinity College , Cambridge , he was awarded Master of Arts in 1679 . [ 4 ] [ 5 ]
#Text=He then obtained a commission in the regiment of foot nominally commanded by his uncle , John Granville , 1st Earl of Bath ( 1628 – 1701 ) .
#Text=He received the honour of knighthood from King James II ( 1685 – 1688 ) .
#Text=He was engaged in military action in the Low Countries .
#Text=In December 1693 he came over from Flanders , waited on King William III , of whom he seems to have been a favourite , and gave him an account of the state of that country . [ 6 ]
#Text=In January 1694 he was gazetted to the colonelcy of the regiment of the Earl of Bath , on the latter 's resignation , [ 7 ] and joined it in Flanders .

#Text=In June 1695 , he fought a duel with Henri Nompar de Caumont , Marquis de Rade , a French Huguenot exile and Colonel of 6th Foot , later the Royal Warwickshire Regiment ; de Rade died of wounds shortly afterwards . [ 8 ]
#Text=On 21 March 1695 – 6 he was appointed by the king Governor of Pendennis Castle in Cornwall . [ 9 ]
#Text=At the end of May he re-embarked for Flanders , where again he got into trouble , " being accused by several officers for illegal practices on his regiment " .
#Text=A court-martial , however , acquitted him . [ 10 ]
#Text=In June 1698 his regiment was ordered to Ireland . [ 11 ]
#Text=In May 1702 Granville accepted the governorship of Barbados , with a salary of £2,000 per annum , but did not sail for the colony until March 1703 . [ 12 ]
#Text=He had scarcely settled when he fell dangerously ill of a fever which had spread across the island . [ 13 ]
#Text=Some of the planters complained to the privy council of his tyranny and extortion .
#Text=After a full hearing on 20 July 1705 , Grenville was " honourably acquitted " , but it was deemed politic to recall him in the following year of 1706 . [ 14 ]
#Text=He died at sea on his passage home in September or October 1706 . [ 15 ]
#Text=Death & succession
#Text=He died at sea on his passage home from Barbados in September or October 1706 . [ 16 ]
#Text=He was unmarried .
#Text=By his will , dated 16 January 1701-2 , and proved at London on 6 November 1706 , [ 17 ] he left his estate to his brother , George Granville , later created Baron Lansdowne
